items.title: Death toll in Lisbon streetcar crash mounts, leaving Portugal reeling
items.standfirst: Lisbon's Elevador da Gloria funicular streetcar has carried tourists in Portugal's capital for more than a century. The cause of its deadly crash remains unclear.
items.content: Lisbon's Elevador da Gloria funicular streetcar has carried tourists in Portugal's capital for more than a century. The cause of its deadly crash remains unclear.

items.standfirst: The crash killed at least 17 people and injured 20 more, some critically, Portuguese authorities say.
items.content: The crash killed at least 17 people and injured 20 more, some critically, Portuguese authorities say.

items.title: What to know about the deadly streetcar derailment in Lisbon
items.standfirst: At least 17 people were killed and a further 21 were injured when Lisbon’s historic Elevador da Gloria streetcar derailed on Wednesday evening, emergency services confirmed. Portuguese authorities said the country would observe a national day of mourning on Thursday.
items.content: At least 17 people were killed and a further 21 were injured when Lisbon’s historic Elevador da Gloria streetcar derailed on Wednesday evening, emergency services confirmed. Portuguese authorities said the country would observe a national day of mourning on Thursday.

items.title: Death toll in Lisbon funicular crash rises to 17
items.standfirst: The death toll in the Lisbon funicular crash has risen to 17, an emergency services official said Thursday. Two of the injured died overnight in a hospital, Margarida Castro Martins, head of Lisbon’s Civil Protection Agency, told reporters. France 24's Sarah Morris has more.
items.content: The death toll in the Lisbon funicular crash has risen to 17, an emergency services official said Thursday. Two of the injured died overnight in a hospital, Margarida Castro Martins, head of Lisbon’s Civil Protection Agency, told reporters. France 24's Sarah Morris has more.

items.title: Lisbon streetcar crash death toll rises to 17 as Portugal observes day of mourning
items.standfirst: A national day of mourning began in Portugal Thursday, after at least 17 people were killed and 22 injured when a popular funicular railway derailed in Lisbon.
items.content: A national day of mourning began in Portugal Thursday, after at least 17 people were killed and 22 injured when a popular funicular railway derailed in Lisbon.

items.title: Lisbon 'in shock' after deadly funicular crash
items.standfirst: Portugal held a day of national mourning on Thursday after a funicular train derailed in Lisbon, killing at least 15 people in one of the capital's most popular tourist spots. With the wreckage of the crash still visible on the city’s streets Thursday morning, many in the Portuguese capital have been left in shock and disbelief by the tragedy, reports France 24’s correspondent Sarah Morris.
items.content: Portugal held a day of national mourning on Thursday after a funicular train derailed in Lisbon, killing at least 15 people in one of the capital's most popular tourist spots. With the wreckage of the crash still visible on the city’s streets Thursday morning, many in the Portuguese capital have been left in shock and disbelief by the tragedy, reports France 24’s correspondent Sarah Morris.

items.title: Portugal holds day of mourning after deadly Lisbon funicular crash
items.standfirst: Portugal declared a day of mourning on Thursday after at least 17 people were killed when Lisbon's Gloria funicular derailed near one of the city’s busiest tourist spots. Lisbon prosecutors said they were launching an investigation into the accident's circumstances.
items.content: Portugal declared a day of mourning on Thursday after at least 17 people were killed when Lisbon's Gloria funicular derailed near one of the city’s busiest tourist spots. Lisbon prosecutors said they were launching an investigation into the accident's circumstances.

items.title: Portugal observes national day of mourning as Lisbon streetcar death toll rises to 17
items.standfirst: The streetcar's crumpled wreckage was still on the downtown road where it crashed Thursday. Officials declined to speculate on whether a faulty brake or a snapped cable may have caused the accident.
items.content: The streetcar's crumpled wreckage was still on the downtown road where it crashed Thursday. Officials declined to speculate on whether a faulty brake or a snapped cable may have caused the accident.(Image credit: Armando Franca)

items.title: At least 15 people dead after streetcar derails in Lisbon
items.standfirst: At least 15 people have died and more than a dozen are injured after a popular streetcar derailed in Lisbon. The funicular that crashed, the Elevador de Gloria, runs between the Baixa and Bairro Alto neighborhoods in Lisbon. Portuguese authorities have announced an investigation into the crash, and local officials have called for three days of mourning.
items.content: At least 15 people have died and more than a dozen are injured after a popular streetcar derailed in Lisbon. The funicular that crashed, the Elevador de Gloria, runs between the Baixa and Bairro Alto neighborhoods in Lisbon. Portuguese authorities have announced an investigation into the crash, and local officials have called for three days of mourning.

items.title: At least 15 people killed and 18 injured in crash of funicular railway in Lisbon
items.standfirst: At least 15 people were killed and 18 were injured in a crash of a popular funicular railway in Lisbon, Portugal, on Wednesday, according to local authorities.
items.content: At least 15 people were killed and 18 were injured in a crash of a popular funicular railway in Lisbon, Portugal, on Wednesday, according to local authorities.

ai_summary: A funicular streetcar derailed in Lisbon, Portugal, causing a deadly crash.
At least 17 people died, and over 20 were injured in the accident.
Portuguese authorities declared a national day of mourning following the tragedy.
The cause of the funicular's derailment remains under investigation by officials.
Some injured individuals died in the hospital, raising the death toll.

items.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin could be heard discussing organ transplants and immortality in an exchange at a military parade.

items.title: Thursday briefing: China flexes its muscle in the tussle for global dominance
items.standfirst: In today’s newsletter: In hosting anti-western leaders at its largest ever military parade, Beijing sent a defiant message that will be heard loud and clear across the worldGood morning. All eyes have been on China this week as the second biggest global economy flexed its muscles.Dozens of world leaders, including from the global south, authoritarian pariah states and the EU, attended China’s largest ever military parade on Wednesday to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the war of resistance against Japanese aggression.UK news | Deputy PM Angela Rayner has admitted she underpaid stamp duty on her £800,000 seaside flat, after coming under intense pressure to be more transparent about her property arrangements.Russia | Vladimir Putin has invited Kim Jong-un to visit Russia during a lengthy meeting in Beijing on the sidelines of China’s biggest military parade, as Kim promised to do “everything I can to assist” Moscow.Police | The Metropolitan police have declined to drop their investigation into the comedy writer Graham Linehan for tweets about trans issues, and said that the law used by officers to detain him needs reviewing.Israel | Israeli drones dropped four grenades near UN peacekeepers in south Lebanon, the agency’s force said on Wednesday, in what it described as “one of the most serious attacks” on its personnel since a November ceasefire.Portugal | A day of national mourning has been declared in Portugal after at least 15 people were killed when Lisbon’s well-known Gloria funicular railway car derailed and crashed on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: In today’s newsletter: In hosting anti-western leaders at its largest ever military parade, Beijing sent a defiant message that will be heard loud and clear across the worldGood morning. All eyes have been on China this week as the second biggest global economy flexed its muscles.Dozens of world leaders, including from the global south, authoritarian pariah states and the EU, attended China’s largest ever military parade on Wednesday to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the war of resistance against Japanese aggression.UK news | Deputy PM Angela Rayner has admitted she underpaid stamp duty on her £800,000 seaside flat, after coming under intense pressure to be more transparent about her property arrangements.Russia | Vladimir Putin has invited Kim Jong-un to visit Russia during a lengthy meeting in Beijing on the sidelines of China’s biggest military parade, as Kim promised to do “everything I can to assist” Moscow.Police | The Metropolitan police have declined to drop their investigation into the comedy writer Graham Linehan for tweets about trans issues, and said that the law used by officers to detain him needs reviewing.Israel | Israeli drones dropped four grenades near UN peacekeepers in south Lebanon, the agency’s force said on Wednesday, in what it described as “one of the most serious attacks” on its personnel since a November ceasefire.Portugal | A day of national mourning has been declared in Portugal after at least 15 people were killed when Lisbon’s well-known Gloria funicular railway car derailed and crashed on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.title: In a 'hot mic' moment, Xi and Putin contemplate immortality and organ transplants
items.standfirst: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin were overheard Wednesday musing about life-extending organ transplants and the possibility of immortality. The discussion was captured by state media microphones before Beijing's massive mlitary parade this week, and highlighted the leaders’ shared vision for the future against a backdrop of geopolitical tensions.
items.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin were overheard Wednesday musing about life-extending organ transplants and the possibility of immortality. The discussion was captured by state media microphones before Beijing's massive mlitary parade this week, and highlighted the leaders’ shared vision for the future against a backdrop of geopolitical tensions.

items.title: Leaders of China, Russia, North Korea appear at military parade
items.standfirst: The leaders of China, Russia and North Korea appeared at a military parade in Beijing. At one point, Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping were heard on a hot mic talking about how organ transplants could lead to human immortality. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer reports.
items.content: The leaders of China, Russia and North Korea appeared at a military parade in Beijing. At one point, Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping were heard on a hot mic talking about how organ transplants could lead to human immortality. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer reports.

items.title: Xi Jinping says world faces ‘peace or war’, as Putin and Kim join him for military parade
items.standfirst: Trump criticises victory day event as China caps off week of diplomatic grandstanding seen as rebuke to the westXi Jinping said the world was facing a choice between peace or war as he held China’s largest-ever military parade, joined by Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un in a show of defiance to the west.Putin and Kim, the authoritarian leaders of Russia and North Korea, were among dozens of world leaders who attended the parade, a massive display of military hardware and personnel, orchestrated to mark the 80th anniversary of the end of the second world war, which China calls the War of Resistance against Japanese Aggression. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.content: The military parade was attended by world leaders including Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un and showcased China’s new weapons.

items.title: Putin hails ties with China as Kim Jong-un arrives in Beijing on eve of parade
items.standfirst: Russian president says relations at ‘unprecedentedly high level’ as dozens of leaders gather for Victory Day eventsVladimir Putin has hailed Russia’s “unprecedentedly” high level of ties with China, as dozens of leaders including the North Korean dictator, Kim Jong-un, arrived in Beijing on the eve of a massive military parade intended to showcase a Chinese-led global order.Putin called China’s leader, Xi Jinping, a “dear friend” after the two held talks at the Great Hall of the People and then at Xi’s personal residence. “Our close communication reflects the strategic nature of Russia-China relations, which are at an unprecedentedly high level,” Putin told Xi, according to a video on the Kremlin’s Telegram channel. “We were always together then, and we remain together now.” Continue reading...
items.content: Russian president says relations at ‘unprecedentedly high level’ as dozens of leaders gather for Victory Day eventsVladimir Putin has hailed Russia’s “unprecedentedly” high level of ties with China, as dozens of leaders including the North Korean dictator, Kim Jong-un, arrived in Beijing on the eve of a massive military parade intended to showcase a Chinese-led global order.Putin called China’s leader, Xi Jinping, a “dear friend” after the two held talks at the Great Hall of the People and then at Xi’s personal residence. “Our close communication reflects the strategic nature of Russia-China relations, which are at an unprecedentedly high level,” Putin told Xi, according to a video on the Kremlin’s Telegram channel. “We were always together then, and we remain together now.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed organ transplants.
The leaders' conversation occurred during a military parade in Beijing.
They also discussed the possibility of living to 150 years old.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un was also present at the military parade.
The exchange was captured by a hot mic during the event.

items.content: The government called on the court to reverse an appeals court ruling that found most of President Donald Trump's tariffs are an illegal use of an emergency powers law.(Image credit: Evan Vucci)

items.content: The Trump administration appealed to the Supreme Court a lower court decision that found many of his tariffs are unlawful.

items.content: A federal appeals court ruled that the president does not have the authority to set sweeping tariffs under the emergency-powers law he invoked.

ai_summary: Donald Trump is asking the Supreme Court to reverse a tariffs ruling.
A lower court found many of Trump's tariffs unlawful.
The government argues the tariffs are legal under emergency powers.
The case involves the use of emergency powers to impose tariffs.
The Supreme Court will decide if it will hear the case.

items.content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will testify in the Senate today after last week's shakeup at the CDC. And, a federal judge says the Trump administration illegally froze billions of Harvard's funds.(Image credit: Alex Wong)

items.title: US judge overturns Trump’s Harvard research funding freeze
items.standfirst: A US judge on Wednesday ordered the Trump administration to reverse funding cuts to Harvard University, which froze more than $2 billion. The cuts were imposed over allegations of antisemitism and bias at the Ivy League school, sparking a legal battle over federal support for higher education.
items.content: A US judge on Wednesday ordered the Trump administration to reverse funding cuts to Harvard University, which froze more than $2 billion. The cuts were imposed over allegations of antisemitism and bias at the Ivy League school, sparking a legal battle over federal support for higher education.

The funding freeze was over allegations of antisemitism and bias.
The judge ordered the Trump administration to reverse the funding cuts.
The case involved a legal battle over federal support for education.

items.title: Paul Doyle pleads not guilty to 31 charges over Liverpool parade incident
items.standfirst: Fifty-three-year-old was arrested after ‘car was driven into crowd of people’ during football celebration in MayA man has pleaded not guilty to 31 charges, including dangerous driving and causing grievous bodily harm with intent, after a car was allegedly driven into a crowd of people in Liverpool.Paul Doyle, 53, was arrested on 29 May after allegedly driving through a crowd of Liverpool football club supporters during the team’s Premier League trophy parade in the city centre on the evening of 26 May. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Man denies deliberately driving into crowd at Liverpool parade
items.standfirst: Paul Doyle, 53, denies 31 charges including causing grievous bodily harm with intent.
items.content: Paul Doyle, 53, denies 31 charges including causing grievous bodily harm with intent.

ai_summary: Paul Doyle pleaded not guilty to 31 charges related to a Liverpool parade incident.
The charges include dangerous driving and causing grievous bodily harm.
Doyle was arrested after a car allegedly drove into a crowd.
The incident occurred during a Liverpool football club trophy parade.
The parade took place in the city center on May 26th.

clusters.title: Taiwan accuses China of breaching international law over drilling
clusters.neutral_headline: Taiwan accuses China of breaching international law over drilling

items.title: Taiwan accuses China of breaching international law over drilling
items.standfirst: Island’s government demands halt to Chinese oil and gas operations in its exclusive economic zoneTaiwan’s government has accused China of breaching international law by drilling for oil and gas inside Taiwan’s exclusive economic zone (EEZ) and immediately demanded it halt the activity.The statement from the office of Taiwan’s president, Lai Ching-te, came after revelations first reported by the Guardian that several Chinese oil rigs and associated vessels had been detected inside Taiwan’s EEZ, near the disputed Pratas Islands, which are under Taiwanese control. Continue reading...
items.content: Island’s government demands halt to Chinese oil and gas operations in its exclusive economic zoneTaiwan’s government has accused China of breaching international law by drilling for oil and gas inside Taiwan’s exclusive economic zone (EEZ) and immediately demanded it halt the activity.The statement from the office of Taiwan’s president, Lai Ching-te, came after revelations first reported by the Guardian that several Chinese oil rigs and associated vessels had been detected inside Taiwan’s EEZ, near the disputed Pratas Islands, which are under Taiwanese control. Continue reading...

items.title: China drilling for oil and gas inside Taiwan’s exclusive economic zone
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Experts say the move could be part of Beijing’s ‘greyzone’ grab for disputed territoryChina is drilling for oil and gas inside Taiwan’s exclusive economic zone (EEZ), a move that analysts believe is likely part of Beijing’s unilateral grab for disputed territory that could also aid a future invasion of Taiwan.During July and August at least 12 oil and gas vessels and permanent structures were detected inside Taiwan’s EEZ – including one within 50km of the restricted-waters border of the Taiwan-controlled Pratas Islands – as well as several steel supports for fixed offshore drilling platforms, called jackets. Their presence inside Taiwan’s EEZ have not been previously reported. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: Experts say the move could be part of Beijing’s ‘greyzone’ grab for disputed territoryChina is drilling for oil and gas inside Taiwan’s exclusive economic zone (EEZ), a move that analysts believe is likely part of Beijing’s unilateral grab for disputed territory that could also aid a future invasion of Taiwan.During July and August at least 12 oil and gas vessels and permanent structures were detected inside Taiwan’s EEZ – including one within 50km of the restricted-waters border of the Taiwan-controlled Pratas Islands – as well as several steel supports for fixed offshore drilling platforms, called jackets. Their presence inside Taiwan’s EEZ have not been previously reported. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Taiwan accuses China of drilling for oil and gas in its exclusive economic zone.
The drilling is happening near the disputed Pratas Islands.
Taiwan demands China halt its oil and gas operations immediately.
Experts believe this is part of China's grab for disputed territory.
At least 12 oil and gas vessels were detected in Taiwan's EEZ.

items.title: Lloyds warns 3,000 staff they face sack for ‘under-performance’
items.standfirst: Around one in 20 staff face ‘performance plans’ as bank seeks to remedy low turnover among some employees Business live – latest updates Lloyds Banking Group is to warn 3,000 staff that they are at risk of being sacked for underperformance, as part of a management overhaul led by chief executive…
items.content: Around one in 20 staff face ‘performance plans’ as bank seeks to remedy low turnover among some employees Business live – latest updates Lloyds Banking Group is to warn 3,000 staff that they are at risk of being sacked for underperformance, as part of a management overhaul led by chief executive…

items.title: Lloyds to warn 3,000 staff they face sack for ‘underperformance’
items.standfirst: With economic uncertainty meaning fewer people leave, bank to put about one in 20 on ‘performance plans’ Business live – latest updatesLloyds Banking Group is to warn 3,000 staff that they are at risk of being sacked for underperformance, as part of a management overhaul led by the chief executive, Charlie Nunn.Bosses have been instructed to rank staff performance, with about 5% of its 63,000-strong workforce due to be put on performance plans that will put their jobs at risk unless they notably improve. About 1,500 of those put on notice could end up losing their jobs. Continue reading...
items.content: With economic uncertainty meaning fewer people leave, bank to put about one in 20 on ‘performance plans’ Business live – latest updatesLloyds Banking Group is to warn 3,000 staff that they are at risk of being sacked for underperformance, as part of a management overhaul led by the chief executive, Charlie Nunn.Bosses have been instructed to rank staff performance, with about 5% of its 63,000-strong workforce due to be put on performance plans that will put their jobs at risk unless they notably improve. About 1,500 of those put on notice could end up losing their jobs. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Lloyds Banking Group will warn 3,000 staff about potential job losses.
The staff are at risk of being fired for underperformance.
This is part of a management overhaul led by the CEO.
About one in twenty staff will be put on performance plans.
Approximately 1,500 employees could lose their jobs.

clusters.title: Dozens die after boat hits tree stump in Nigeria
clusters.neutral_headline: Boat Accident in Nigeria: Dozens Killed

items.title: Ukraine seeks security guarantees at 'coalition of the willing' meeting in Paris
items.standfirst: Some 30 Western leaders were holding talks in Paris on Thursday with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky over security guarantees for Kyiv in the event of a peace deal with Russia, hoping to do enough to persuade the United States to back their efforts. France 24's correspondent in Kyiv Gulliver Cragg takes a look at what Ukraine will be hoping to get out of the meeting of the so-called "coalition of the willing".
items.content: Some 30 Western leaders were holding talks in Paris on Thursday with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky over security guarantees for Kyiv in the event of a peace deal with Russia, hoping to do enough to persuade the United States to back their efforts. items.title: Europe 'ready' to offer security guarantees as Zelensky meets leaders in Paris
items.standfirst: European leaders and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky are to meet in Paris on Thursday in a new effort to pile pressure on Vladimir Putin after he vowed Russia will fight on in Ukraine if no peace deal is reached. France 24's senior reporter Catherine Norris Trent and international affairs editor Philip Turle take a look at what's at stake in the talks in the French capital.
items.content: European leaders and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky are to meet in Paris on Thursday in a new effort to pile pressure on Vladimir Putin after he vowed Russia will fight on in Ukraine if no peace deal is reached. items.title: Zelensky meets European leaders in Paris after Putin vows to continue Ukraine war
items.standfirst: European leaders held talks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Paris on Thursday in a renewed push to pressure Russian President Vladimir Putin after he vowed to continue his war in Ukraine unless a peace deal is reached. Western frustration has been mounting over what leaders describe as President Putin’s refusal to negotiate an end to Moscow’s three-and-a-half-year invasion of Ukraine.
items.content: European leaders held talks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Paris on Thursday in a renewed push to pressure Russian President Vladimir Putin after he vowed to continue his war in Ukraine unless a peace deal is reached. Western frustration has been mounting over what leaders describe as President Putin’s refusal to negotiate an end to Moscow’s three-and-a-half-year invasion of Ukraine.

items.title: France fines Google, Shein record sums over cookie law violations
items.standfirst: France’s data protection watchdog CNIL on Wednesday fined Google €325 million ($380 million) and fast-fashion retailer Shein €150 million ($175 million) for violating cookie rules. The record penalties target two platforms with tens of millions of French users, marking among the heaviest sanctions the regulator has imposed.
items.content: France’s data protection watchdog CNIL on Wednesday fined Google €325 million ($380 million) and fast-fashion retailer Shein €150 million ($175 million) for violating cookie rules. The record penalties target two platforms with tens of millions of French users, marking among the heaviest sanctions the regulator has imposed.

clusters.title: Old master painting looted by Nazis recovered a week after being spotted in Argentinian property listing
clusters.neutral_headline: Nazi-Looted Painting Recovered in Argentina

items.title: Old master painting looted by Nazis recovered a week after being spotted in Argentinian property listing
items.standfirst: Portrait of a Lady by the Italian master Giuseppe Ghislandi handed over by daughter of the late Nazi financier Friedrich KadgienAuthorities in Argentina have recovered an 18th-century painting stolen more than 80 years ago by the Nazis from a Jewish art dealer in Amsterdam, a week after it was spotted by chance in a real estate listing.The painting, the long-lost Portrait of a Lady (Contessa Colleoni) by the Italian master Giuseppe Ghislandi, was looted in the second world war. It was handed over on Wednesday to the Argentinian judiciary by the daughter of the late Nazi financier Friedrich Kadgien, Patricia Kadgien, who has been under house arrest with her husband since Tuesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Portrait of a Lady by the Italian master Giuseppe Ghislandi handed over by daughter of the late Nazi financier Friedrich KadgienAuthorities in Argentina have recovered an 18th-century painting stolen more than 80 years ago by the Nazis from a Jewish art dealer in Amsterdam, a week after it was spotted by chance in a real estate listing.The painting, the long-lost Portrait of a Lady (Contessa Colleoni) by the Italian master Giuseppe Ghislandi, was looted in the second world war. It was handed over on Wednesday to the Argentinian judiciary by the daughter of the late Nazi financier Friedrich Kadgien, Patricia Kadgien, who has been under house arrest with her husband since Tuesday. Continue reading...

items.title: Argentine police recover Nazi-looted Italian painting spotted in property ad
items.standfirst: Argentine police have recovered an 18th century painting stolen from a Jewish art dealer by the Nazis during World War II just over a week after it appeared in a property ad. Prosecutors said Wednesday that "Portrait of a Lady", which was photographed hanging in the home of the daughter of a senior SS officer, had been returned by the woman's lawyer.
items.content: Argentine police have recovered an 18th century painting stolen from a Jewish art dealer by the Nazis during World War II just over a week after it appeared in a property ad. Prosecutors said Wednesday that "Portrait of a Lady", which was photographed hanging in the home of the daughter of a senior SS officer, had been returned by the woman's lawyer.

ai_summary: An 18th-century painting looted by Nazis was recovered in Argentina.
The painting was spotted in a real estate listing and identified.
The painting is "Portrait of a Lady" by Giuseppe Ghislandi.

The painting was handed over by the daughter of a Nazi financier.

items.title: Shein opens investigation after shirt listing displayed image resembling Luigi Mangione
items.standfirst: Company removed image on website that appeared to show Mangione in a white shirt reportedly priced just under $10The clothing company Shein said it has opened an internal investigation after its website briefly displayed a shirt listing featuring an image resembling Luigi Mangione, the man accused of killing Brian Thompson, the CEO of UnitedHealthcare, in New York last year.The image appeared to show Mangione in a short-sleeved white shirt, and the top was reportedly priced at just under $10. Continue reading...
